text: (audience applauds)
How's everyone doing?
Did you arrive safely in Italy?
I had my little hiccups on the way here.
How about yourself?
Yeah. (laughs)
I was reminded of my overreliance on technology
on my way here.
So, but then I remembered that this was just the way
how it used to be like 20 years ago anyway.
So, didn't make me feel as stupid.
Who of you was here last year?
All right, that's a lot of you.
So, I had the pleasure to give the keynote
of last year's conference, but I'm pretty glad
that I don't have to do a full talk today.
Since today, my honor is to
act as your host, as your MC.
I'm Johannes.
Yeah, thank you. (laughs)
(audience applauds)
Yeah, I'm Johannes.
I live in Berlin.
I do a few different things.
My main thing is running a product company
called Overengineering Studio.
I was accused of overengineering things.
So, I now just own it and made the theme of it.
I'm also part-time and an advisor to Effectful
and trying to contribute to Effect.
And a few other things, I'm also the host
of the Cause and Effect
podcast, which we started last year.
And the past, you might know me
from being the founder of Prisma.
So, to get a few things out of the way,
a few notes on housekeeping.
First of all, this event would have not been possible
without some really, really awesome sponsors.
So, a big thank you to Inato from France,
who's in the medical field, clinical trial marketplace,
who are a huge supporter of Effect
for a super, super long time,
contributing, already sponsored, last year's conference.
So, huge thank you to Inato.
(audience applauds)
(audience applauds)
And also from France, we have the awesome folks
from Evryg here, who are a consultancy based in Paris.
They're also the hosts of the Effect meetup in Paris.
I think we have quite a few folks from Evryg here.
So, also a huge thank you to them for sponsoring.
(audience applauds)
(audience applauds)
And obviously, we wouldn't be here
if it wasn't for Effectful as well,
who is the company behind Effect.
So, huge thank you, particularly to the organizing team,
to Mirela for making all of this happen.
So, thank you.
(audience applauds)
So, your primary attention
should be on the talks, obviously,
but if you wanna connect to the outside,
we have wifi here, it works okay-ish.
If you're not connected, you can use a QR code,
or you can...
All right, now the cursor's out of the way.
So, you can connect to this one.
Also, restrooms, if you've been here yesterday
at the workshops, you might already know,
but restrooms are just downstairs.
And we might not need it for an emergency,
but there is an emergency exit over there,
but you can also use it for non-emergency reasons
just to enjoy the view on the beautiful ocean.
So, it's just behind you, and I highly encourage you to,
if you take a break, go outside.
It's super, super nice.
I mean, that's what this venue is all about.
And I hope we're all having a great time,
and we should let the rest of the world know as well.
So, feel free to take pictures, share your thoughts
on whatever platform you feel like it.
But yeah, with all of that out of the way,
I just wanna get back into the theme of Effect.
And what for me, Effect is all about,
and I mentioned that at last year's keynote,
for me, Effect is all about taming complexity.
Where the quality bar is rising and rising
for the products we're trying to build.
And that is a lot of work.
There's so much complexity,
and I'm trying to reduce the accidental complexity
as much as possible and keep it
to the existential complexity.
And I feel this is where we just need a great foundation.
That is what Effect gives us,
and I think this is what brings a lot of us here.
So, I just wanted to start with that
and take a quick stroll through last year
since last year we got a lot of stuff done.
The team got a lot of stuff done.
So, starting with Effect itself,
I was actually doing a little,
I was doing a little AI-based scraping thing
of how many releases we had,
and I think it was over 3,000 releases in total
because there are so many different packages.
But more meaningfully, we had 13 really,
I don't wanna call them major releases,
but they almost deserved a term.
Really big releases of Effect itself,
which now encapsulates schema, et cetera.
And so, huge thank you to the core team working on that.
That's amazing progress.
(audience applauding)
But besides just the code,
we need to learn about the code,
and we've also made amazing progress,
particularly, Giulio has made incredible progress
on the documentation.
So, I tried to get a grasp
and try to roughly quantify how much progress
we've made in the documentation.
If you've been around with Effect for a long time,
this was always the Achilles heel.
There's supposedly great technology,
but how the heck should I learn about it?
And we've made so much progress in that regard.
We've been already in a much better spot a year ago
from compared to the year before.
But just over the last year,
just for the reference docs itself,
when you go to effect.website/docs,
the docs there, in content wise,
has more than doubled compared over the last year.
But beyond that, we now also have really, really great
JSDoc coverage for most methods and effects.
So, right in your editor,
you get helpful explanations, helpful examples, et cetera.
We worked on the docs infrastructure,
so just to make the entire site experience faster.
We very recently improved the search.
And we also given it's not just us anymore,
learning effect, but also those like big AI matrices.
So, we also made the docs AI ready.
So, I just want to give a huge shout out to Giulio
for working relentlessly on making the docs better
for all of us.
(audience applauds)
Another huge quality of life improvement.
Oh yeah, this is our new YouTuber.
Maxwell has worked for quite a
bit on the Effect playground,
which came together as like a small idea
and then really like compounded in meaning.
And I think we're not, I'm using it on a daily basis
when I'm experimenting with something with Effect.
And the goal was to lower the barrier to entry
to just play around with Effect.
And I'm really excited how it turned out.
It's also where we embedded the Effect dev tools right away
and we intend to make it better over time.
So, really excited about this one.
Great work Maxwell for shipping this last year.
(audience applauds)
And also over the last year,
we kicked off the cause and Effect podcast.
We already had two amazing guests here.
We have Attila who was the first guest.
We have Michael from Markprompt who was the second guest.
And also, so thank you so much for the guests
and also thank you so much for Davide there
for like doing all the amazing work on the video content.
(audience applauds)
And also last year, we also
already got a bit of recognition
from the broader web ecosystem
and we got an award for that,
which luckily we had someone from the community
take the award.
So thank you so much for you for going there
to take the award and yeah, really excited
that we got a bit of recognition from the outside.
(audience applauds)
Yeah, but also just overall traction
like has more than 10X last year by NPM numbers.
That might be AI and might be other things,
but I think overall people are coming around to Effect.
We've also more than 4X the GitHub stars from last year.
So let's see where we are next year.
And there's now almost 20,000 GitHub projects
that are using Effect in one way or another.
And I couldn't figure out the trajectory of this,
but I remember the number being a lot smaller last year.
But more meaningfully, there is also now more and more
companies and enterprises using Effect in production.
And I think that's really a meaningful change
compared to last year where companies were just getting
their hands dirty with Effect.
And now over the last year,
have really rolled it out in production.
So really, really excited about that.
That like effect helps small companies, small startups,
small projects, but also large companies.
And I'm super, super excited about that.
And I think that's not a coincidence, not a surprise
because TypeScript is winning.
Like there's so many exciting advancements
in regards to TypeScript.
I think it's such a great trade-off.
Just when was it like one or two weeks ago
when Microsoft blew us all away with making TypeScript,
whatever acts faster.
I can't wait for, to actually get my hands on that
for my own projects.
Michael has already done some tests
and I think it mostly compiled just without any problems
and ran how much faster?
7x faster in the Effect repository.
So, and I'm sure the folks at Microsoft have a lot more
improvements there in the store as well.
So super excited about that.
And we can also just run TypeScript with Node, with Bun.
Super excited about that.
And if you're looking at the conference schedule,
you might actually think you're at an AI conference today
since we have like, we have almost,
I think we have five talks about AI,
but that's also for a good reason.
Because I think this sort of this virtual cycle
where effect makes it a lot easier to build AI products.
I think this is when you build AI products,
this is where you're kind of in the eye of the storm
of complexity where everything can go wrong.
You're dealing with streams,
you're dealing with like API endpoints,
they're timing out that you need to retry, etc.
All of those things, Effect shines that.
But we've made it even easier
through the Effect AI package.
There's also some interesting work on making it easier
to build MCP servers through Effect.
But also the virtual cycle goes the other way around.
AI now makes it easier to build code with Effect.
Very recently we've added the LLM.txt file,
but cursor is already pretty good
working with Effect as well.
We have already for quite a
bit built our own AI driven apps
with the Effect bot you might know from Discord.
And also again, we're looking into MCP
to make everything better,
maybe even in our Effect DevTools.
And so I just wanna also encourage you,
if you're using AI to build Effect apps,
please let us know where we could do something better.
Like the LLM.txt file was mostly due to like some requests
and encouragement from the community.
And we're looking for feedback to help those AI systems
to help you get the most out of it when working on Effect.
So with that, I wanna already hand it over
to our next speakers.
We're starting with Maxwell Brown,
who will open the conference with his keynote
about Effect AI.
But we'll also later hear from Tim Smart
about Effect Cluster, a little bit later,
we're hearing from Mattia about Effect DevTools.
And so those are just like from the Effect core team.
And I won't reveal yet what Michael will talk about.
But yeah, without further ado,
please give it up for Maxwell Brown.
(audience applauds)
